Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Situation2: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Story:
I walked beside my little sister, our backpacks bouncing in rhythm as we made our way down Maple Street. She was quiet, her eyes scanning the sidewalk for cracks to avoid. I kept glancing at my phone, waiting for a reply from Mia. My heart pounded with every vibration, knowing our last conversation had ended with her saying, “Maybe we need a break.” I wanted to call her, to fix things, to prove I could resolve our fights like a good boyfriend should. But my sister’s hand slipped into mine, and I remembered Mom’s words: “Always look out for each other.” 

Suddenly, a group of older kids appeared ahead, laughing too loudly, blocking the path. My sister squeezed my hand tighter. I felt the weight of her trust, the expectation to keep her safe. At the same time, my phone buzzed again—Mia’s name lighting up the screen. I could feel the pull from both sides: my sister needing me here, Mia needing me to answer, to not give up on us. My chest tightened as I tried to figure out who needed me more in this moment, torn between being the brother she counted on and the boyfriend Mia wanted me to be.
